summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment in favor of Massey's motion for a temporary restraining order against him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Jackson, Mississippi, alleges that Massey violated Section 712A.19b(3)(a)(ii) and Rule 712B.9(a) thereunder by failing to provide sufficient evidence to justify his termination of parental rights.  According to the complaint, Massey also failed to provide any evidence that he had adequately addressed his issues with substance abuse, domestic violence, and lack of suitable housing for his children.  In addition, the complaint alleges that, despite repeated requests from Massey, he did not participate in any child custody proceedings because he had been ordered to do so by the court.  As a result, the court terminated his parental rights without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.  Massey has also consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently restrains and enjoins him from future violations of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4), and orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.   The court's order also prohibits Massey from serving as an officer or director of a public agency, and prohibits him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security-related product or service.  On the other hand, the SEC's order requires the court to determine whether a person is entitled to the right to terminate parental rights based on reasonable grounds, such as whether he has a history of domestic violence or a prior felony conviction, and requires that the court consider the merits of the case before it.  For example, the order requires that a court determine whether an individual has a reasonable basis for terminating parental rights when it finds reasonable reason to terminate a person's parental rights at a time when the individual is not a member of any Indian tribe.  It also requires that an individual be required to provide proof of a bona fide relationship with the person at issue, including that the individual has an attorney and that he/she has a legal source of income, and that a reasonable likelihood that the child will be placed in a foster home over the parent's home is a reasonable probability that the parent will be able to provide for the child's needs.  Additionally, the Court requires the individual to provide a "reasonable basis for termination" when he or she has not provided any evidence to support the individual's claim of having any Native American heritage.
